docs.lead_paragraph: Cognitive therapy and medication are regarded as equally effective in treating depression. But they work in very different ways, according to a study released yesterday comparing brain scans of depressed patients before and after treatment. The study, which was published in The Archives of General Psychiatry, involved 14 patients who attended 15 to 20 sessions of therapy and 13 comparably depressed patients who were treated with paroxetine, an antidepressant better known by its brand name, Paxil.
docs.abstract: Dr Helen Mayberg of Rotman Research Institute of Toronto leads study, published in Archives of General Psychiatry, that shows combination therapy using drugs and therapy are best for treating depression; findings show that cognitive therapy and drugs affect different areas of brain, which do not overlap; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Cognitive therapy and medication are regarded as equally effective in treating depression. But they work in very different ways, according to a study released yesterday comparing brain scans of depressed patients before and after treatment.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Little by little, research has helped Americans chip away at what was once a runaway epidemic of premature heart disease, which claimed the lives of far too many people, especially men, in their 40's and 50's. We learned through extensive and costly long-term studies that cigarette smoking, elevated serum cholesterol levels, uncontrolled high blood pressure and diabetes placed people at greatly increased risk of heart disease and sudden cardiac death.

headline.main: Hunt for Heart Disease Tracks a New Suspect

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column examines C-reactive protein, or CPR, and its impact on catastrophic cardiovascular events; holds that cholesterol screening fails to identify 50 percent of people having heart attacks each year in US; Dr Daniel G Hackam and Dr Sonia S Anand of McMaster University (Ontario) contend in article published in American Medical Assn journal, that primary emergent factor in determining cardiovascular risk is CPR and even small increases predict future heart problems for asymptomatic people; experts suggest those individuals thought to be at intermediate risk for cardiovascular problems should have CPR tested; holds that 1 milligram per liter or more needs aggressive action to reduce levels; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Little by little, research has helped Americans chip away at what was once a runaway epidemic of premature heart disease, which claimed the lives of far too many people, especially men, in their 40's and 50's.    We learned through extensive and...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chinese government's decision on Monday to start killing all civet cats in captivity in Guangdong Province is belated and only partly counters the government's tolerance of the sale of the animals in markets, a SARS expert for the World Health Organization said. On Monday, Chinese and W.H.O. scientists said they had confirmed that a 32-year-old television producer in Guangdong had SARS. No other cases have been identified, and the source of the producer's infection is unknown, they said.
docs.abstract: Chinese officials and World Health Organization scientists report lone case of SARS in Guangdong Province (China) in tandem with government mandate to destroy all civet cats in captivity in region; Dr Klaus Stohr, WHO expert on SARS, stresses culling of cats should be done carefully to avoid transmission of disease to workers and should involve systematic testing of animals to help answer questions about illness, which is believed to have jumped from animals to humans in Guangdong in November 2002; SARS outbreak and subsequent research discussed (M)
docs.snippet: The Chinese government's decision on Monday to start killing all civet cats in captivity in Guangdong Province is belated and only partly counters the government's tolerance of the sale of the animals in markets, a SARS expert for the World Health...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Male Pill: A Biography of a Technology in the Making,'' by Dr. Nelly Oudshoorn, Duke University Press, $21.95. Other than the advent of Viagra, sexual intervention topics have focused primarily on women: contraceptive pills, in vitro fertilization and hormone replacement therapy, among them.
docs.abstract: Dr Nelly Oudshoorn, University of Twente (Netherlands) gender and technology professor, writes book The Male Pill: Biography of Technology in the Making; discusses quest for male contraceptive and gives reasons why she believes that sexual intervention topics have been focused primarily on women; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever causes mad cow disease is practically indestructible. Even after being steamed, frozen, disinfected, zapped with ultraviolet light or bombarded with X-rays, tissue from sick animals can still spread the illness. Though scientists argue over whether the infectious agent is a bit of protein known as a prion or a mysterious viruslike particle, they agree it is devilishly hard to destroy. And that gives rise to a queasy thought: given that animals and people can contract mad cow disease by ingesting infected tissue, is there a safe way to dispose of diseased carcasses?

headline.main: With Diseased Animals, Disposal Isn't Simple

docs.abstract: Health officials, concerned about best way to dispose of animal carcasses that may or may not be contaminated, explore options like tissue digestors; Joseph H Wilson, Waste Reduction by Waste Reduction Inc president, describes alkaline hydrolysis process, of which company holds patent, and its advantages; holds that after process liquefies 1,500-pound cow all that is left is 76 pounds of bone and 375 gallons of sterile water solution, both of which can be used as fertilizer; tissue digestors are currently used by Agriculture Department; there are roughly 30 to 40 machines in use in United states and company cites rapid growth; holds that concerns over chronic wasting disease and fear of mad cow are factors in increased business; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Whatever causes mad cow disease is practically indestructible. Even after being steamed, frozen, disinfected, zapped with ultraviolet light or bombarded with X-rays, tissue from sick animals can still spread the illness. Though scientists argue over...

keywords.value: WASTE REDUCTION BY WASTE REDUCTION INC

docs.lead_paragraph: Older Americans are far more likely than previous generations to have kept their teeth, but a newly published survey found huge variations by state and income. The results of the survey of almost 50,000 people older than 65 conducted in 2002 were published last month in The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, the journal of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Land of the Toothless No More

docs.abstract: Recent survey published in Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's journal Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report finds that resident state and income directly affect ability of Americans to keep their teeth into old age; survey finds that most older people today have lost only five teeth or fewer compared to large numbers of people in 1950's who did not have any teeth as seniors; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Older Americans are far more likely than previous generations to have kept their teeth, but a newly published survey found huge variations by state and income.    The results of the survey of almost 50,000 people older than 65 conducted in 2002 were...

docs.lead_paragraph: The position of the arm when blood pressure is being checked can make the difference between a reading that leads to treatment and one that does not, a study released yesterday concluded. Other research has found that many health care workers do not follow guidelines for how to take blood pressure readings.

headline.main: Blood Pressure: It's All in the Arm

docs.abstract: University of California (San Diego) researchers, publishing letter in Annals of Internal Medicine on blood pressure study, hold that position of arm during blood pressure readings affects result; suggest consistency in position of arm from reading to reading is most accurate way to determine blood pressure in individual (S)
docs.snippet: The position of the arm when blood pressure is being checked can make the difference between a reading that leads to treatment and one that does not, a study released yesterday concluded.    Other research has found that many health care workers do...

docs.lead_paragraph: Eye injuries from paintball games have increased among children, even as the protective gear for the sport has improved, according to a study released yesterday. The study, which was published in the journal Pediatrics, said the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission estimated the number of emergency room visits for eye injuries caused by paintballs at 545 in 1998 and more than 1,200 in 2000. More than 40 percent of those injuries were believed to involve children, the study said.
docs.abstract: Dr David A Listman of St Barnabas Hospital (Bronx, NY) publishes report in journal Pediatrics that shows eye injuries from paintball games are increasing despite efforts to utilize more safety gear; Consumer Product Safety Commission estimates number of emergency room visits for paintball related eye injuries at 545 in 1998 and more than 1,200 in 2000; Listman suggests better regulation of paintball gun use; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Eye injuries from paintball games have increased among children, even as the protective gear for the sport has improved, according to a study released yesterday.    The study, which was published in the journal Pediatrics, said the federal Consumer...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Jacqueline Turner's daughter Riley was only 8 months old, she could let her mother know she was thirsty for milk by pumping her fingers against her palm. Or that she wanted more cereal by touching her fingertips together. Or ask for a ball, or her stuffed dog, or a book -- all without saying a word. She used hand gestures taught to her by her mother. Why teach signs to a baby who is not deaf? Mrs. Turner, a Spanish-language interpreter from Beaverton, said she bought a book and video about teaching signs to babies to help eliminate the frustration Riley had in not being able to communicate, as well as Mrs. Turner's own frustration in not understanding her.

headline.main: Before Baby Talk, Signs and Signals

docs.abstract: Dr Linda Acredolo of University of California (Davis) and Dr Susan W Goodwyn of California State University (Stanislaus) are both experts in child development who have recently completed study on effects of teaching signs to babies before they can talk; findings show that second graders, who were encouraged to sign before they were two, scored average of 12 points higher on IQ tests than babies that did not learn signs; supporters of signing hold that not only does signing provide avenue of communication, but increases parent to child bond and can diminish tantrums during terrible two's; Dr Elizabeth Bates, University of California (San Diego) Center for Research in Language director, contends that any system of communication with babies enchances their capacity for learning and language; parents are being encouraged not to look at teaching signs as way to give child future competitive edge, but instead as way to enhance relationship with infant; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When Jacqueline Turner's daughter Riley was only 8 months old, she could let her mother know she was thirsty for milk by pumping her fingers against her palm. Or that she wanted more cereal by touching her fingertips together. Or ask for a ball, or...

docs.lead_paragraph: Now that ephedra is to be banned, the millions of people who have been taking the supplement to lose weight or control it may find themselves looking for an alternative. But weight-loss and nutrition experts nationwide say that no other over-the-counter supplements advertised as weight-loss aids are as effective as ephedra. ''I'm not pushing ephedra, and I wouldn't recommend it to anybody, but several very good studies have shown that ephedra combined with caffeine promotes weight loss,'' said Dr. Ken Fujioka, director of the Nutrition and Metabolic Research Center at the Scripps Clinic in San Diego. ''I don't know of any other over-the-counter preparation that has shown that kind of consistent effect.''
docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration recently announced ban on sale of ephedra, weight-loss drug, after review of 16,000 reports of adverse reactions, including death; drug has been only effective over-the-counter supplement for weight loss and ban, although supported by medical community, leaves ephedra users without comparable alternative; prescription and non-prescription alternatives for ephedra discussed; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Now that ephedra is to be banned, the millions of people who have been taking the supplement to lose weight or control it may find themselves looking for an alternative. But weight-loss and nutrition experts nationwide say that no other...
